found_in: Africa and parts of Asia, especially open grasslands and savannas
fun_fact: Antelopes can run up to 95 km/h, making them one of the fastest land animals on Earth!

found_in: Europe and Asia, in woodlands, grasslands, and hedgerows
fun_fact: Badgers are excellent diggers and can excavate a burrow system called a 'sett' that may be used by generations of families.

found_in: Found on every continent except Antarctica, in caves, forests, and urban areas
fun_fact: Bats are the only mammals capable of true sustained flight, and they use echolocation to navigate in complete darkness.

found_in: North America, Europe, and Asia, in forests, mountains, and tundra
fun_fact: Bears don't truly hibernate — they enter a lighter sleep called torpor, and mother bears can give birth during this state!

found_in: Found worldwide except Antarctica, in meadows, gardens, and forests
fun_fact: A single honeybee will produce only about 1/12 of a teaspoon of honey in its entire lifetime.

found_in: Found on every continent except Antarctica, in soil, forests, ponds, and deserts
fun_fact: About 1 in every 4 known animal species on Earth is a beetle — they are the most diverse group of animals!

found_in: North America, primarily in grasslands and prairies
fun_fact: Despite their massive size, bison can sprint up to 55 km/h and jump nearly 2 meters vertically.

found_in: Europe, Asia, and North Africa, in forests and scrublands
fun_fact: Wild boars have a remarkable sense of smell and can detect food buried up to a meter underground.

found_in: Found worldwide except Antarctica, in gardens, meadows, and tropical forests
fun_fact: Butterflies taste with their feet — they have taste sensors on their legs to identify plants when they land.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal, adapted to nearly every environment
fun_fact: Cats spend about 70% of their lives sleeping — that's around 13 to 16 hours a day!

found_in: Found worldwide on every continent except Antarctica, on plants and trees
fun_fact: A caterpillar essentially dissolves itself into a liquid 'soup' inside its chrysalis before reforming into a butterfly.

found_in: Central and West Africa, in tropical rainforests and savannas
fun_fact: Chimpanzees share approximately 98.7% of their DNA with humans, making them our closest living relatives.

found_in: Found worldwide, especially in warm tropical and subtropical regions
fun_fact: Cockroaches can hold their breath for up to 40 minutes and survive being submerged in water for half an hour.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal
fun_fact: Cows have best friends and become stressed when separated from them — they form deep social bonds!

found_in: North and Central America, in deserts, forests, grasslands, and cities
fun_fact: Coyotes are highly adaptable and have actually expanded their range as humans have spread — they now thrive in major cities.

found_in: Found worldwide in oceans, freshwater, and on land in tropical regions
fun_fact: Crabs communicate with each other by drumming or waving their claws in specific patterns.

found_in: North America, Europe, and Asia, in forests, fields, and urban areas
fun_fact: Crows can recognize and remember human faces, and have been known to hold grudges against people who have wronged them.

found_in: Found worldwide except Australia and Antarctica, in forests and grasslands
fun_fact: Male deer grow and shed their antlers every single year — they are the fastest-growing tissue in the animal kingdom.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal
fun_fact: Dogs can smell 10,000 to 100,000 times better than humans — they can even detect diseases like cancer.

found_in: Found worldwide in oceans and some rivers
fun_fact: Dolphins sleep with one half of their brain at a time, keeping one eye open to watch for predators.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal; wild relatives in Africa and Asia
fun_fact: Donkeys have an incredible memory and can remember a place or person they met up to 25 years ago.

found_in: Found worldwide near freshwater habitats like ponds, rivers, and wetlands
fun_fact: Dragonflies are the most successful hunters in the animal kingdom, catching their prey about 95% of the time.

found_in: Found worldwide on every continent except Antarctica, near lakes, rivers, and ponds
fun_fact: Ducks' feathers are so waterproof that the skin underneath stays completely dry even when they dive.

found_in: Found worldwide except Antarctica, in mountains, forests, and open landscapes
fun_fact: Eagles have eyesight 4–8 times more powerful than humans and can spot a rabbit from nearly 3 km away.

found_in: Sub-Saharan Africa and South/Southeast Asia, in savannas, forests, and grasslands
fun_fact: Elephants are the only animals known to perform rituals around death — they mourn their deceased and return to visit bones.

found_in: Africa, Southern Europe, and the Americas, near saltwater lagoons and lakes
fun_fact: Flamingos are actually born white or grey — their iconic pink color comes from pigments in the algae and shrimp they eat.

found_in: Found worldwide in virtually every habitat
fun_fact: Flies can taste with their feet — their taste sensors are 10 million times more sensitive to sugar than human tongues.

found_in: Found worldwide in forests, grasslands, mountains, and urban areas
fun_fact: Foxes use the Earth's magnetic field to judge distance and direction when pouncing on prey hidden under snow.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal; wild relatives in mountainous regions of Asia and Europe
fun_fact: Goats have rectangular pupils that give them a 320-degree field of vision, helping them spot predators from almost all directions.

found_in: Originally from East Asia; now found worldwide in ponds and aquariums
fun_fact: Goldfish actually have a memory span of several months — the idea that they only remember 3 seconds is a complete myth!

found_in: Found worldwide near lakes, rivers, and wetlands
fun_fact: Geese fly in a V-formation to save energy — each bird benefits from the updraft of the one in front, reducing effort by up to 65%.

found_in: Central and West Africa, in tropical and subtropical forests
fun_fact: Gorillas have unique noseprints just like human fingerprints — researchers use them to identify individual gorillas in the wild.

found_in: Found worldwide except polar regions, in grasslands, meadows, and forests
fun_fact: Grasshoppers can jump 20 times their own body length — equivalent to a human jumping about 40 meters!

found_in: Originally from Syria and Turkey; found worldwide as a popular pet
fun_fact: Hamsters can stuff their stretchy cheek pouches with food so much that their cheeks can become as wide as their whole body.

found_in: Europe, Asia, North America, and Africa, in open grasslands and fields
fun_fact: Unlike rabbits, hares are born fully furred with open eyes and can run within hours of birth.

found_in: Europe, Asia, and Africa, in hedgerows, woodlands, and gardens
fun_fact: A hedgehog's spines are hollow hairs made of keratin — a single hedgehog can have up to 7,000 spines!

found_in: Sub-Saharan Africa, in rivers, lakes, and wetlands
fun_fact: Hippos produce a natural sunscreen — a reddish oily fluid that also acts as an antimicrobial agent.

found_in: Africa and Asia, in tropical and subtropical forests
fun_fact: When a female hornbill nests, the male seals her inside a tree cavity with mud, leaving only a small slit to pass food through.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal; wild horses in Central Asia and Americas
fun_fact: Horses can sleep both standing up and lying down — they have a special locking mechanism in their legs to rest without falling.

found_in: The Americas, from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego, in gardens and forests
fun_fact: Hummingbirds are the only birds that can fly backwards — their wings beat 50–80 times per second!

found_in: Africa and parts of Asia, in savannas, grasslands, and woodlands
fun_fact: Spotted hyenas have a more powerful bite relative to their size than lions, and their laugh-like call is actually a sign of nervousness.

found_in: Found worldwide in all oceans, from shallow coasts to deep seas
fun_fact: Jellyfish have no brain, heart, or blood — they are 95% water and have existed for over 500 million years!

found_in: Australia, in grasslands, savannas, and open woodlands
fun_fact: A group of kangaroos is called a mob, and joeys (babies) live in their mother's pouch for about 8 months after birth.

found_in: Eastern Australia, in eucalyptus forests and woodlands
fun_fact: Koalas sleep up to 22 hours a day to conserve energy, since their diet of eucalyptus leaves is very low in nutrition.

found_in: Found worldwide except polar regions, in gardens, meadows, and forests
fun_fact: Ladybugs can play dead to avoid predators, and a single ladybug can eat up to 5,000 aphids in its lifetime!

found_in: Africa and Asia, in forests, mountains, grasslands, and deserts
fun_fact: Leopards are incredibly strong and can haul prey heavier than themselves up into trees to keep it safe from scavengers.

found_in: Sub-Saharan Africa and a small population in India's Gir Forest
fun_fact: A lion's roar can be heard from up to 8 km away and is used to communicate territory and call to the pride.

found_in: Found worldwide except Antarctica, in deserts, forests, and grasslands
fun_fact: Some lizards can detach their own tail to escape predators — the tail wriggles to distract the predator while the lizard escapes.

found_in: North Atlantic Ocean, on rocky and sandy sea floors
fun_fact: Lobsters don't age in the traditional sense — older lobsters are actually more fertile, and some may live over 100 years.

found_in: Found worldwide except Antarctica, near standing water and warm humid areas
fun_fact: Only female mosquitoes bite — they need blood to develop their eggs. Males feed exclusively on nectar and plant juices.

found_in: Found worldwide on every continent except Antarctica
fun_fact: Moths navigate using moonlight as a compass, which is why they get confused and circle artificial lights at night.

found_in: Found worldwide in almost every habitat, especially near human settlements
fun_fact: Mice communicate using ultrasonic calls far beyond human hearing range — they even sing elaborate songs to attract mates.

found_in: Found worldwide in all oceans, from shallow tidal pools to deep seas
fun_fact: Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood — and each of their eight arms has its own mini 'brain' that can act independently!

found_in: Democratic Republic of Congo, in dense tropical rainforests
fun_fact: Despite its zebra-like stripes, the okapi's closest living relative is the giraffe — it was unknown to science until 1901.

found_in: Borneo and Sumatra, in tropical rainforests
fun_fact: Orangutans build new sleeping nests in trees every single night, and sometimes add pillows and roofs made of leaves.

found_in: Found worldwide near rivers, lakes, and coastlines
fun_fact: Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to keep from drifting apart — these groups are called 'rafts'!

found_in: Found worldwide on every continent except Antarctica
fun_fact: Owls cannot move their eyeballs — they compensate by rotating their heads up to 270 degrees.

found_in: Found worldwide as a working domesticated animal
fun_fact: Oxen are not a separate species but specially trained adult cattle — they have been used as working animals for over 6,000 years.

found_in: Found worldwide in shallow marine and brackish waters
fun_fact: Oysters can change their biological sex multiple times throughout their lives depending on environmental conditions.

found_in: Central and Southwest China, in mountain forests with dense bamboo
fun_fact: Giant pandas eat bamboo for up to 16 hours a day and must consume 12–38 kg of it daily just to survive.

found_in: Tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, Asia, and the Americas
fun_fact: Parrots don't just mimic sounds — some species genuinely understand words and can use them in context.

found_in: Found worldwide near coastal areas, lakes, and rivers
fun_fact: Pelicans can hold up to 13 liters of water in their expandable throat pouches — about 3 times more than their stomach!

found_in: Southern Hemisphere, primarily Antarctica, South America, South Africa, and New Zealand
fun_fact: Penguins propose to their mates by giving them a pebble — in penguin society, pebbles are a prized currency for nest building.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal
fun_fact: Pigs are smarter than dogs and can learn to play video games with joysticks to earn food rewards.

found_in: Found worldwide in cities, towns, and open countryside
fun_fact: Pigeons can recognize themselves in a mirror — one of only a handful of animals to pass the self-recognition test.

found_in: Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Americas, in forests and rocky hillsides
fun_fact: Porcupine quills are coated with natural antibiotics that help prevent infection if they accidentally quill themselves.

found_in: North and Central America, in forests, farmland, and suburban areas
fun_fact: 'Playing possum' is an involuntary response — opossums actually faint from shock and cannot consciously choose to fake death.

found_in: North and Central America, in forests, marshes, and urban areas
fun_fact: Raccoons' front paws become even more sensitive when wet, which is why they often appear to 'wash' their food.

found_in: Found worldwide near human settlements
fun_fact: Rats laugh when they are tickled — they emit ultrasonic chirps of joy that humans cannot hear without special equipment.

found_in: Arctic and Subarctic regions of Europe, Asia, and North America
fun_fact: Reindeer are the only deer species where both males and females grow antlers, and their eyes change color with the seasons.

found_in: Africa and Asia, in grasslands, savannas, and tropical forests
fun_fact: A rhino's horn is made entirely of keratin — the same protein found in human fingernails and hair.

found_in: Found worldwide near beaches, mudflats, and wetlands
fun_fact: Some sandpipers migrate over 30,000 km round-trip every year — among the longest migrations of any bird.

found_in: Tropical and temperate waters worldwide, in shallow seagrass beds and coral reefs
fun_fact: Seahorses are the only animal species where the male becomes pregnant and gives birth to the young.

found_in: Found worldwide in oceans, especially in colder Arctic and Antarctic waters
fun_fact: Seals can slow their heart rate to as low as 4 beats per minute while diving to conserve oxygen.

found_in: Found worldwide in all oceans, from shallow coasts to deep open water
fun_fact: Sharks are older than trees — they have been swimming in Earth's oceans for over 450 million years.

found_in: Found worldwide as a domesticated animal; wild relatives in mountains of Central Asia
fun_fact: Sheep can recognize and remember up to 50 different sheep faces for over 2 years — and remember human faces too.

found_in: Found worldwide except Antarctica, Ireland, New Zealand, and some islands
fun_fact: Snakes smell the air using their forked tongue, which collects scent particles and delivers them to a special organ in their mouth.

found_in: Found worldwide near human settlements on every continent except Antarctica
fun_fact: House sparrows were introduced to North America in 1851 with just 16 birds — today there are hundreds of millions there.

found_in: Found worldwide in all oceans, from shallow coastal waters to the deep sea
fun_fact: The giant squid has the largest eyes of any living creature — each eye can be as large as a basketball.

found_in: Found worldwide in forests, parks, and urban areas
fun_fact: Squirrels accidentally plant millions of trees every year by forgetting where they buried their nuts.

found_in: Found worldwide in all oceans, from tidal pools to deep sea floors
fun_fact: Starfish have no brain or blood — they use seawater to pump nutrients through their body, and can regenerate lost arms!

found_in: Europe, Asia, North America, and Australia, near lakes and rivers
fun_fact: Swans mate for life, and if one partner dies, the other may die of a broken heart — a condition called 'stress cardiomyopathy'.

found_in: South and Southeast Asia, in forests, grasslands, and mangroves
fun_fact: Tiger stripes are like human fingerprints — no two tigers have the same stripe pattern, and the pattern also appears on their skin.

found_in: North America, in forests and grasslands; domesticated worldwide
fun_fact: Wild turkeys can fly at speeds of up to 89 km/h for short distances — domesticated turkeys have lost this ability.

found_in: Found worldwide on every continent except Antarctica, in oceans, lakes, and rivers
fun_fact: Sea turtles use Earth's magnetic field as a GPS system to navigate thousands of kilometres back to the exact beach where they were born.

found_in: Found in all oceans worldwide, from polar seas to tropical waters
fun_fact: Blue whales are the largest animals ever known to have existed — their hearts alone are the size of a small car!

found_in: North America, Europe, and Asia, in forests, tundra, and grasslands
fun_fact: Wolves can howl at frequencies that travel over 10 km, and each wolf has a unique howl like a fingerprint.

found_in: Australia and Tasmania, in forests, grasslands, and scrublands
fun_fact: Wombats are the only animals in the world that produce cube-shaped droppings — they use them to mark territory.

found_in: Found worldwide except Australia, New Zealand, and polar regions, in forests
fun_fact: Woodpeckers peck up to 20 times per second — their skull is specially reinforced with thick bone and a unique beak structure to absorb the shock.

found_in: Africa, primarily in savannas, grasslands, and open woodlands
fun_fact: Every zebra's stripe pattern is unique like a fingerprint, and the stripes may help confuse biting flies who struggle to land on the moving patterns.
